questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not an absolute contraindication for breast-conserving surgery (BCS)?

options.label: A
options.text: Prior radiation therapy to the chest wall or breast

questions.explanation:
Absolute Contraindications
  • Pregnancy (Option D ruled out) because after BCS postop radiotherapy will be necessary which is not possible in case pregnancy.
  • Multicentric Disease
  • Diffuse malignant microcalcifications on mammogram suggests widespread disease, making complete excision with clear margins unlikely (Option B ruled out)
  • Prior Radiation Therapy to the Chest Wall or Breast  cannot give radiation again, which is essential after BCS(Option A ruled out)
  • Extensive Positive Pathological Margins

Relative Contraindications
  • Active Connective Tissue Disease Involving the Skin (e.g., Scleroderma)
  • Large tumor size relative to breast size or tumors greater than 5 cm
  • Large pendulous breast
  • Centrally located tumor
  • Extensive DCIS (often requires aggressive management, such as mastectomy, due to the risk of recurrence).
  • Homozygous for ATM Mutation
  • Known or Suspected Li-Fraumeni Syndrome (p53 Mutation)
  • Known or Suspected Genetic Predisposition to Breast Cancer (e.g., BRCA1, BRCA2) - Prophylactic mastectomy is preferred for individuals with high genetic cancer risk to reduce the likelihood of developing breast cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following age groups is a greenstick fracture most commonly observed?
questions.explanation:
Definition

A greenstick fracture is an incomplete fracture commonly seen in children, where one cortex of the bone is broken while the other cortex remains intact, resembling the bending and partial breaking of a young, flexible bamboo.

Common Sites
  • Most Common Fracture in Children: Occurs before epiphyseal closure, predominantly in children aged 4 to 10 years.
  • Most Affected Bone: Typically involves the forearm bones (radius and ulna).

Clinical Features
  • Patients often present with pain, tenderness, and swelling over the affected area.
  • There may be a limitation in the range of motion.
  • The mechanism of injury often involves a fall or a direct blow to the arm.

Diagnosis
  • X-ray: Shows a small opening or a line at one cortex with the other cortex remaining intact.
  • Radiographic appearance resembles a bending of the bone rather than a complete break.

Analogy

The term "greenstick" is derived from the analogy of young bamboo; when young bamboo is broken, only one cortex breaks, similar to this type of fracture, whereas mature bamboo may break both cortices.

Treatment
  • Conservative Management: Treatment typically involves immobilization with a Plaster of Paris (POP) cast.
  • In cases where the intact cortex is also fractured, additional casting may be required to ensure complete healing and prevent complications such as delayed union or non-union.
  • Surgical Intervention: Generally not performed before epiphyseal closure, as conservative management is sufficient for healing.

Prognosis

Greenstick fractures generally heal well with appropriate treatment, and complete recovery is expected within a few weeks, depending on the child's age and bone growth potential.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient presents with difficulty seeing objects in the right half of the visual field in both eyes. Based on this clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely location of the lesion affecting the visual pathway?
questions.explanation:
Components of Visual Pathway

Retina
  • First-order Neurons: Bipolar cells in the inner nuclear layer of the retina.
  • Second-order Neurons: Ganglion cells in the retina; their axons form the optic nerve.

Optic Nerve
  • Carries visual information from the retina to the optic chiasm.
  • Temporal and Nasal fibres of the same eye.

Optic Chiasma
  • Partial decussation occurs
  • Nasal fibres cross to the opposite side, while temporal fibres remain ipsilateral.

Optic Tract
  • Carries visual information from the optic chiasms to the Lateral Gebiculate body(LGB).
  • Temporal fibres of the same eye and Nasal fibres of the opposite eye.
  • The lesion causes Homonymous Hemianopia in the opposite eye.

Lateral Geniculate Body (LGB)
  • Third Order Neurons: Relay visual information to the visual cortex.

Optic Radiations
  • Meyer's Loop: Carries information from lower retinal quadrants to the inferior part of the visual cortex.
  • Baum’s Loop (Dorsal): Carries information from upper retinal quadrants to the superior part of the visual cortex.

Occipital Cortex

The primary visual cortex (V1), corresponding to Brodmann area 17, is situated on the medial side of the occipital lobe, particularly along the borders of the calcarine fissure.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents with symptoms of acute onset blurred vision, dry mouth, tachycardia, and urinary retention. His medical history is unremarkable, and he denies any recent illnesses or medication use. On examination, his pupils are dilated and unreactive to light. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his presentation?
Which of the following agents inhibits the action of an agonist on a receptor or the subsequent response but does not have any effect of its own?
questions.explanation:
Drug C (Option C): Antagonist


 
  • It prevents the action of an agonist on a receptor or the subsequent response but does not have any effect of its own. 
  • Naloxone, an opioid receptor antagonist, is commonly used to reverse opioid overdose.

Drug A (Option A): Agonist

 
  • It activates a receptor to produce an effect similar to the physiological signal molecule (e.g., morphine at opioid receptors).

Drug D (Option D): Inverse Agonist


 
  • It activates a receptor to produce an effect opposite to that of an agonist (e.g., Rimonabant at cannabinoid receptors).

Drug B (Option B): Partial Agonist
  • It activates a receptor to produce a submaximal effect and can block the action of a full agonist (e.g., Buprenorphine at opioid receptors).

Super Agonist
  • Not directly relevant to opioid overdose treatment but produces a maximum response greater than that of the endogenous agonist (e.g., BMS-986121 at GLP-1 receptors).

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with behavioral changes and involuntary movements over the past several weeks. Neurological examination revealed ataxia and myoclonus. He passed away after 4 months, and biopsy findings of the brain tissue are shown below. Based on these findings, which of the following statements is false regarding this condition? Proteinaceous particles with single-stranded RNA cause it. It results from the misfolding of PrPsc to PrPc. Spongiform transformation is a characteristic histopathological feature It is associated with a good prognosis if diagnosed early. Familial forms are associated with specific genetic mutations.
questions.explanation:
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (M/C)
  • Genetic: Familial form caused by PRNP mutation.
  • Transmission: Iatrogenic
  • Symptoms:
    • Dementia.
    • Associated pronounced involuntary jerking muscle contractions on sudden stimulation (startle myoclonus) and cerebellar dysfunction (ataxia).
  • Histopathogenesis:
    • Spongiform transformation of the cerebral cortex.
  • Prognosis: Uniformly fatal with average survival < 7 months after the onset of symptoms.

Kuru disease
  • PAS & Congo: red positive.
  • Kuru plaques: Extracellular aggregated abnormal PrP.

Fatal familial insomnia

Bovine spongiform encephalopathy

questions.text: A 35-year-old veterinarian presents with intermittent fever, sweating, and joint pain. Blood cultures are performed, but the initial results are negative. Further laboratory tests show a significant titer of 640 in the Standard Agglutination Test (SAT). Which of the following characteristics is least likely associated with the causative organism?

options.label: D
options.text: Destroyed by heat at 60°C in 10 minutes

questions.explanation:
Morphology

Biochemical Properties

Growth & Susceptibility

Small, non-motile, aerobic, Gram-negative coccobacilli (Option A ruled out)

Catalase positive

Do not grow well on standard laboratory media

Non-capsulated and non-spore forming

Oxidase positive (except B. neotomae and B. ovis)

Destroyed by heat at 60°C in 10 minutes (Option D ruled out)

Often exhibit a bipolar staining appearance

Urease positive (Option B ruled out)

Killed by 1% phenol in 15 minutes
 

Utilize oxygen but do not typically ferment carbohydrates

Killed by pasteurization

Test

Description

Key Points

Standard Agglutination Test (SAT)

Tube agglutination test using serial dilutions of patient's serum and killed B. abortus antigen
  • Significant titer: 160 or more.
  • Acute brucellosis titer: 640 or more within 3-4 weeks.
  • Prozone phenomenon common.
  • False positives with cholera, tularemia, yersinia infection, or immunization

Complement Fixation Test

Detects IgG antibodies
  • Valuable in chronic cases

ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay)

Distinguishes between IgM and IgG antibodies
  • Useful for differentiating acute from chronic infections

Rapid Tests

Includes rapid dipstick tests and Rose Bengal card test
  • Quick results.
  • Can be used for initial screening

Characteristic

Details

Morphology

Small, non-motile, aerobic, Gram-negative coccobacilli, Non-capsulated, non-spore forming, Bipolar staining

Biochemical Properties

Catalase positive, Oxidase positive (except B. neotomae and B. ovis), Urease positive, Utilize oxygen, do not ferment carbohydrates

Growth & Susceptibility
  • Do not grow well on standard media.
  • Destroyed by heat at 60°C in 10 min, Killed by 1% phenol in 15 min, Killed by pasteurization.

Zoonotic Nature

Affects goats, sheep, cattle, buffaloes, pigs. Human infection through contact or consumption.

Symptoms

Intermittent fever, loss of appetite, nausea, muscular and articular pains, fatigue, sweating, joint pain.

Blood Culture
  • Trypticase soy broth or brucella broth. Biphasic blood culture (Castaneda method).
  • Large blood volume (5 ml). Incubation: 37°C, 5-10% CO2, 6-8 weeks. 30-50% positive cases. Bone marrow cultureshave a higher yield.

Serological Tests

SAT: Significant titer 160+, Acute 640+, Complement Fixation: IgG detection, ELISA: Distinguishes IgM & IgG. Rapid Tests: Dipstick, Rose Bengal

Antibiotics

Adults: Doxycycline 45 days, Streptomycin 2 weeks, Children: Cotrimoxazole + Rifampicin/Gentamycin.

Vaccination

No human vaccine, Occupational risk: Attenuated live vaccine, Animals: B. abortus strain 19 vaccine.

Muscles of the Anterior Axioappendicular Region

Muscle

Origin

Insertion

Nerve Supply

Actions

Pectoralis Major (Option A ruled out)
  • Anterior surface of the medial two-thirds of the clavicle
  • Front of the manubrium and sternum up to the 6th costal cartilages
  • Second to sixth costal cartilages and sternal end of the 6th rib
  • Aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle

Lateral lip of the bicipital groove of the humerus (via bilaminar tendon)

Medial and lateral pectoral nerves
  • Adducts and medially rotates the arm
  • Flexes the arm (clavicular part)
  • Extends the flexed arm against resistance (sternocostal part)

 

Pectoralis Minor (Option B ruled out)

3rd, 4th, and 5th ribs near the costochondral junction

Medial border and upper surface of the coracoid process

Medial and lateral pectoral nerves
  • Protracts the scapula
  • Lowers the point of the shoulder

Subclavius (Option C ruled out)

First rib at the costochondral junction

Subclavian groove on the middle third of the clavicle

Nerve to subclavius (from upper trunk of brachial plexus)
  • Stabilizes the clavicle during shoulder movements
  • Protects axillary vessels and brachial plexus

Serratus Anterior (Option D)

Eight digitations from the upper 8 ribs and fascia over the intercostal muscles

Costal surface of the medial border of the scapula

Long thoracic nerve (C5, C6, C7)
  • Protracts scapula
  • Rotates scapula upward for arm abduction beyond 90 degrees
  • Stabilizes the scapula during weight-bearing activities
  • Assists in forced inspiration

questions.text: Match the variants of Migraine in Column A with their characteristic clinical features in Column B: Column A Column B 1. Ophthalmoplegic Migraine A. Associated with blindness and scintillating scotomas 2. Cluster Headaches B. Retro-orbital pain in males 3. Retinal Migraine C. Associated with occulomotor palsy 4. Familial Hemiplegic Migraine D. Presents with hemiplegia and can be confused with stroke E. Diagnosis often involves neuroimaging to rule out cerebrovascular accidents
questions.explanation:
Ophthalmoplegic Migraine
  • Ophthalmoplegic migraine can present with neurological deficits, such as third nerve palsy, which may include symptoms like ptosis and squinting.
  • It typically causes severe pain that can lead to vision impairment

Cluster Headaches
  • Cluster headaches are known for their unilateral, severe pain typically located around the eye, often described as retro-orbital pain.
  • They are more common in males and can be associated with other symptoms such as nasal congestion and watering of the eyes.

Retinal Migraine
  • Associated with transient vision loss or blindness due to vasospasm of the retinal arteries.
  • Symptoms such as scintillating scotomas are also present.

Familial Hemiplegic Migraine
  • Rare type of migraine that includes hemiplegia (temporary paralysis on one side of the body) as a symptom.
  • Because of this, it can easily be confused with a stroke.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with symptoms of bloating, abdominal pain, and irregular bowel habits consistent with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). After confirming the diagnosis, which of the following dietary interventions is most likely to provide symptomatic relief for this patient?

A 24 y/o male presents with intermittent pain and discharge at the natal cleft after experiencing recurrent abscesses in the area. He reports that the symptoms worsen after prolonged sitting and has a history of coarse hair. Upon examination, a midline opening is noted in the natal cleft. What is the most appropriate initial management for this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Complete surgical excision of the sinus

questions.correct_answer: C. Drainage through a midline incision
questions.explanation:
Treatment Type

Description

Conservative Treatment
  • For mild cases: cleaning, hair removal, and hygiene maintenance.
  • Cauterization with silver nitrate or laser in less complex cases.

Acute Abscess Treatment
  • Drainage through a small longitudinal incision over the abscess (Option C).
  • Thorough cleaning of the abscess cavity to remove granulation tissue and hair.

Surgical Treatment

Procedures include:

  • Laying open sinus tracks (with/without marsupialisation)
  • Complete excision (with/without primary closure)
  • Off-midline closure techniques (Limberg, Z-plasty, Karydakis procedures).
  • Bascom Procedure: Lateral incision to clean the sinus cavity, excise midline pits, and leave lateral wounds open to heal secondarily.
  • Flap Procedures: Used if initial treatments fail or if the sinus recurs.

Cause vasodilation; especially important in counteracting vasoconstriction from sympathetic nerves or angiotensin II

Bradykinin (Option A)

Increase

Functions similarly to prostaglandins by causing vasodilation

Nitric Oxide (Option B)

Increases

Important for maintaining normal renal excretion of sodium and water; decreased production linked to hypertension

Angiotensin II

Biphasic effect on GFR

Constricts efferent arterioles, increasing glomerular pressure; severe constriction decreases GFR ​

Sympathetic Nerves (Option C)

Decrease

Cause vasoconstriction, especially under stress or volume depletion

Norepinephrine, Epinephrine, Endothelin

Decreases

Vasoconstriction

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient with recurrent abdominal pain undergoes an endoscopic biopsy of the small intestine. Location

Function

Absorptive Columnar Cells (Enterocytes) (Option A)

Luminal surface (villi)

Absorption of amino acids, carbohydrates, and lipids

Scattered among columnar cells, increasing in number towards ileum

questions.text: All of the following can be management options for complicated cases of TTTS except?

options.label: A
options.text: Laser ablation of deep arteriovenous anastomosis

options.label: C
options.text: Single fetal reduction of the recipient twin

questions.correct_answer: C. Single fetal reduction of the recipient twin
questions.explanation:
Definition
  • TTTS is characterized by deep AV anastomosis between monochorionic twins.
  • More common in MCDA>MCMA

Clinical Findings
  • Donor Twin: Oligohydramnios (<2 cm), anemia, hypovolemia, hypotension, growth restriction, "stuck" appearance.
  • Recipient Twin: Polyhydramnios (>8 cm), polycythemia, hypervolemia, hypertension, larger size, risk of heart failure and hydrops fetalis.

Diagnostic Criteria
  • Ultrasound Findings: MCDA twin pregnancy, discrepant amniotic fluid volumes, size discrepancy.
  • Doppler Studies: Abnormal blood flow patterns, such as absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the donor twin's umbilical artery.
  • Hematologic Findings: Hemoglobin difference >5 g%, estimated fetal weight discrepancy >25%.

Management

(Option A,B and D ruled out)
  • Laser Ablation
  • Amnioreduction
  • Septostomy
  • Selective Reduction of donor twin

questions.text: A 28 y/o G3P2 woman at 39 weeks with a H/O previous C-Section with spontaneous labor in the labor ward has just delivered a healthy baby girl via vaginal delivery. She has been diagnosed with severe anemia (Hb 8 gm/dL). The obstetric team is concerned about the risk of PPH. What is the next best step in her management to prevent PPH?

options.label: D
options.text: Administration of oxytocin infusion for at least one hour after delivery

questions.correct_answer: D. Administration of oxytocin infusion for at least one hour after delivery
questions.explanation:
PREVENTION OF PPH

Antenatal Measures

Intranatal Measures
  • Maintain hemoglobin > 10 gm/dL (Option A)
  • Screen high-risk patients and deliver in well-equipped hospitals
  • Conduct blood grouping for all women
  • Localize the placenta in women with previous cesarean delivery using USG/MRI (Option C)
  • Plan delivery of women with morbidly adherent placenta by a senior obstetrician with blood products ready
  • Active management of the third stage of labor
  • Continue oxytocin infusion for at least one hour after delivery in induced/augmented labor
  • Administer oxytocin 5 IU slow IV during cesarean section (Option B)
  • Use Carbetocin (100 μg IV over 1 min.) to prevent PPH
  • Check the uterovaginal canal for trauma after a difficult labor or instrumental delivery
  • Observe for two hours post-delivery to ensure uterus contraction before transferring to the ward
  • Prefer local or epidural anesthesia over general anesthesia in forceps, ventouse, or breech delivery
  • Allow spontaneous placental separation during cesarean section to reduce blood loss
  • Examine the placenta and membranes routinely for completeness

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic with complaints of jaundice, fatigue, and abdominal pain for the past 5 days. The child has a history of poor appetite and dark urine. On examination, he is mildly icteric, with tender hepatomegaly but no splenomegaly. His liver function tests reveal elevated ALT and AST levels, with a significant rise in total and direct bilirubin. Anti-HAV IgM is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Supportive care with hydration and monitoring

questions.correct_answer: C. Supportive care with hydration and monitoring
questions.explanation:
Category

Details

Diagnosis
  • Anti-HAV IgM antibodies: Detectable during symptoms and remains positive for 4-6 months.
  • Anti-HAV IgG antibodies: Provides long-term immunity and appears within 8 weeks of symptom onset.
  • Elevated levels: ALT, AST, bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, 5′-nucleotidase, γ-glutamyl transpeptidase.

Complications
  • Full recovery is typical.
  • Acute liver failure (ALF): Rare, particularly in older adolescents, adults, and immunocompromised patients.
  • Prolonged cholestatic syndrome: Leads to pruritus and fat malabsorption, resolves without long-term effects.
  • Acute Relapsing Hepatitis
  • Fulminant hepatitis (Acute Hepatitis E > A)

Treatment
  • Supportive care: Intravenous hydration, antipruritic agents, and fat-soluble vitamin supplementation for cholestatic disease.
  • Monitor for signs of ALF.

Prevention
  • Vaccine: Two inactivated vaccines, administered intramuscularly in a 2-dose schedule (second dose 6-12 months after the first). Recommended for children >12 months.
  • Isolation: Infected individuals should be isolated for 2 weeks before and 1 week after jaundice onset.
  • Hand hygiene.
  • Immunoglobulin (Ig) Prophylaxis: For preexposure and postexposure prophylaxis, especially in children <12 months, immunocompromised individuals, those with chronic liver disease, and those allergic to the vaccine.

Prognosis
  • Excellent prognosis with no long-term sequelae.

questions.text: Which of the following schemes is most closely related to providing unemployment relief to eligible individuals who have lost their jobs in specific circumstances?

Scheme

Description

Key Features

Atal Beemit Vyakti Kalyan Yojana
  • Provides financial assistance to employees covered under the ESI Act, 1948, who become unemployed.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient diagnosed with mild Crohn's disease affecting the ileocecal region presents to your clinic. The patient has mild symptoms with no significant systemic involvement. What is the most appropriate first-line drug to prescribe for this patient to induce remission in mild Crohn's disease?
questions.explanation:
Category

Mild Crohn's Disease

Moderate to Severe Crohn's Disease

Induction Therapy
  • First-line: Budesonide (preferred for ileocecal disease) (Option D) or aminosalicylates (e.g., mesalamine).
  • Prednisone for those who do not respond to budesonide.
    (Option A)
  • Alternative: Enteral nutrition.
  • First-line: Corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone for short term) or biologics
    Anti-TNF agents (Infliximab, Adalimumab) (Option C)
  • Anti-integrin therapy (Vedolizumab)
  • Anti-interleukin therapy (Ustekinumab)
  • Combination therapy: Anti-TNF agents plus immunomodulators (Azathioprine, 6-MP) (Option B)

Maintenance Therapy
  • First-line: Continue aminosalicylates if effective.
  • Alternative: Thiopurines (azathioprine, 6-MP) for patients intolerant to aminosalicylates.
  • Anti-TNF monotherapy: Long-term for maintaining remission.
  • Combination therapy: Anti-TNF agents with immunomodulators (for severe cases or history of nonresponse to biologics).
  • Continue anti-integrin or anti-interleukin agents for those induced by these therapies

Monitoring
  • Regular follow-up to monitor symptoms and inflammation.
  • Ileocolonoscopy 6-12 months post-remission. Drug level monitoring and fecal calprotectin to assess mucosal healing.

Management of complex fistulising Crohn's disease

Management

Drug therapy

With Abscess:

  • Prompt surgical drainage with seton placement.
  • Initiate anti-TNF therapy post-drainage.
 

Without Abscess:

  • EUA with seton placement and anti-TNF therapy combined with antibiotics.
  • Removal of setons based on clinical response and imaging.
  • Consider switching biologics or further surgical intervention if fistula does not heal.

Initial Therapy:

  • Anti-TNF agents + antibiotics (metronidazole or ciprofloxacin).
 

Alternative/ Adjunctive:

  • Thiopurines (azathioprine, 6-MP), other biologics (vedolizumab, ustekinumab, upadacitinib).

questions.text: A 50-year-old immunocompromised patient presents with cough, fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. She reports having recently cleaned out an old barn where she encountered large amounts of bird droppings. Upon examination, she has mild tachycardia and her lungs exhibit scattered crackles on auscultation. A chest X-ray shows patchy infiltrates and several calcified nodules. Histopathology and (LPCB) mount of colonies grown in culture are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.explanation:
Histoplasmosis

Causative Agent

Histoplasma capsulatum; thermally dimorphic fungus.

  • H. capsulatum var. capsulatum: Causes classical histoplasmosis.
  • H. capsulatum var. duboisii: Causes African histoplasmosis.

Epidemiology

Endemic to central and eastern USA; also found in Africa.

Route of transmission

Thrives in soil, decaying trees, and bird droppings.

Inhalation of fungal spores.

Clinical manifestations

Classical histoplasmosis is often asymptomatic.

Calcified lesions.

Pulmonary disease mimics tuberculosis.

Disseminated histoplasmosis can occur.

Infection of the reticuloendothelial system causes:

  • Lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, fever, and anaemia

Skin and mucous membrane: Granulomatous and ulcerative lesions.

African Histoplasmosis:

  • It primarily affects the skin, subcutaneous tissues, and bones
  • Lungs are rarely involved, and disseminated cases are infrequent

Specimens for Diagnosis

Blood, urine, bone marrow, lesions

 

Diagnosis

Microscopy:

  • Stained smears of the specimens show small intra- and extracellular yeast cells
 

Culture:

  • Blood agar and Sabouraud agar show characteristic growth
  • White, cottony, mycelial growth with large thick-walled spherical spores with tuberculate (finger-like projections)
 

Serodiagnosis:

  • Antibody titers increase in progressive disease
  • Antigen tests on urine and serum are helpful for immunocompromised individuals.

Skin Test:

  • Delayed hypersensitivity to histoplasmin confirms exposure

Treatment

Amphotericin-B for two to four weeks followed by a year of itraconazole (Option A ruled out)

  • Punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine.

109
  • Attempt to murder.
  • Punishment: Up to life imprisonment or up to 10 years and fine. If injury occurs, may extend to life imprisonment.

110
  • Attempt to commit culpable homicide.
  • Punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment or fine, or both. If injury occurs, may extend to 7 years.

226
  • Attempt to commit suicide.
  • Punishment: Up to 1 year imprisonment or fine.

questions.text: While demonstrating the Koebner phenomenon as depicted in the image below to a group of medical students, a dermatology professor explains the pseudo-Koebner phenomenon as well. Which of the following is a disease that exhibits the pseudo-Koebner phenomenon?
questions.explanation:
Category

Cause

Examples

Images

Category 1 (True koebnerization)

Development of lesions at sites of trauma.
  • Psoriasis
  • Lichen planus (Option A)
  • Vitiligo

Psoriasis

 

Category 2 (Pseudo koebnerization)

Non-immunological and occurs due to auto-inoculation and not trauma.
  • Verruca vulgaris (warts)
  • Molluscum

Warts

 

Category 3 (Occasional koebnerization)

The phenomenon is infrequent or occurs only in specific circumstances.
  • Darier disease
  • Erythema multiforme (Option D).

Erythema multiforme

 

Category 4 (Dubious association with trauma)

Limited evidence or conflicting reports regarding the role of trauma in lesion formation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with elevated ammonia levels presents with confusion and disorientation. Which of the following is not a typical symptom of ammonia toxicity?
questions.explanation:
Hyperammonemia

  • Occurs in advanced liver disease and certain genetic disorders of amino acid metabolism.
  • It can lead to loss of consciousness, coma, convulsions and may be fatal.
  • This is due to:
  1. Depletion of α-ketoglutarate from the citric acid cycle to form glutamate and glutamine.
  2. Reduced ATP production.
  3. Inhibition of α-ketoglutarate and pyruvate dehydrogenases by elevated ammonia levels.

Neurotoxic effects of hyperammonemia
  • Tremors (Option B)
  • Slurred speech (Option A)
  • Drowsiness
  • Vomiting
  • Cerebral edema
  • Blurred vision (Option D)
  • Potential coma and death

Causes

  • Genetic causes: Urea cycle disorders and organic acidurias
  • Hepatic encephalopathy
  • Cor pulmonale
  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Renal failure

Management
  • Low-protein/high-calorie diet
  • Antibiotics to reduce bacterial load ( ￬ urease-producing bacteria)
  • Lactulose to decrease intestinal ammonia production

questions.explanation:
Disease caused by staphylococcus

Key features

Primary infection

Furuncle

Superficial skin infection develops in hair follicles, sebaceous gland, or sweat gland.

Carbuncle

Development of one or more abscesses in adjacent subcutaneous tissues due to the spread of infection from a furuncle.

Impetigo

The exfoliative toxin produced causes bullous impetigo, characterized by blisters.

Non-bullous impetigo is caused by streptococcus.

Acute osteomyelitis

Bacterial growth usually concentrates in a terminal blood artery of the metaphysis of a long bone, resulting in bone necrosis and persistent suppuration.

  • Caused by strains producing the PVL leukocidin.

Endocarditis
  • In drug addicts

Scalded skin syndrome

Toxic shock syndrome
  • TSST-1 (Toxic Shock Syndrome Toxin)
  • Early findings: Fever, vomiting, diarrhea, muscle pain

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents with a history of abdominal surgery performed 3 days ago. She reports worsening abdominal distension and has not passed stool since the surgery. On examination her abdomen is distended, and bowel sounds are absent. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this condition?

options.label: C
options.text: X-ray shows dilated bowel loops and air-fluid levels

questions.correct_answer: C. X-ray shows dilated bowel loops and air-fluid levels
questions.explanation:
Etiology
  • Abdominal surgery.
  • Uremia.
  • Mesenteric ischemia.
  • Retroperitoneal hematoma.
  • Intra-abdominal sepsis.
  • Dyselectrolytemia (e.g., hypokalemia) (Option D).
  • Drugs affecting intestinal motility:
    • Opiates.
    • Antipsychotics.

Pathophysiology
  • Neurogenic- enteric nervous system and CNS
  • Inflammatory- histamine, IL-6 and IL-8, monocytes and macrophages
  • Enteric hormones and neuropeptides- motilin, substance P, and vasoactive intestinal peptide [VIP]
  • Perioperative electrolyte disturbances
  • Opioids
  • Duration of surgery and extent of surgical trauma

Clinical Features
  • Abdominal distension.
  • Abdominal discomfort.
  • Non-colicky pain.
  • Vomiting.
  • Non-passage of feces and flatus.
  • Absence of bowel sounds.

Investigations

IOC: Abdominal X-ray. (Option C)

Findings:

  • Dilated bowel loops.
  • Gas in the colon and rectum.
  • Multiple air-fluid levels.

Management

Decompression: Nasogastric aspiration.

 

Diet: Restrict oral intake until bowel sounds return or the patient starts passing feces and flatus.

 

Treatment of Underlying Cause:

  • Correct dyselectrolytemia (e.g., hypokalemia).
  • Discontinue medications affecting motility (e.g., opiates).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a previous lower-segment cesarean section is in labor at 39 weeks of gestation and wants to attempt a trial of labor. Which of the following factors is not a benefit of the trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC) as compared to elective repeat Cesarean section.?

options.label: B
options.text: Reduced need for future cesarean deliveries.

options.label: C
options.text: Reduced risk of uterine wound dehiscence.

questions.correct_answer: C. Reduced risk of uterine wound dehiscence.
questions.explanation:
Selection Criteria of Cases for TOLAC (ACOG)
  • One (RCOG) or two (ACOG) previous lower segment transverse scar.
  • Nonrecurring indication for prior cesarean section.
  • Pelvis adequate for the fetus.
  • Continued labor monitoring possible.
  • Availability of resources (anesthesia, blood transfusion and theatre) for an emergency cesarean section within 30 minutes of the decision.
  • Informed consent of the woman.

Contraindications for TOLAC (indications for Cesarean Delivery)
  • Previous classical or inverted T-shaped uterine incision , myomectomy scar
  • Previously >2 LSCS
  • Pelvis contracted or suspected CPD.
  • Presence of other complications in pregnancy: Obstetric (pre-eclampsia, malpresentation, placenta previa) or medical.
  • Resources limited for emergency cesarean delivery or patient refusal for TOLAC.
  • History of prior uterine rupture

Benefits of TOLAC

Complications of Unsuccessful TOLAC
  • Decreased maternal morbidity (infection and others).
  • Reduced length of hospital stay. (Option D)
  • Decreased need for blood transfusion.
  • Decreased risk of abnormal placentation (Option A) and need for successive cesarean delivery in next pregnancy. (Option B)
  • Maternal Uterine wound dehiscence. (Option C)
  • Uterine rupture (0.5-1%).
  • Increased blood transfusion.
  • Increased risks of hysterectomy due to uterine rupture.
  • Infections increased maternal morbidity.
  • Perinatal: Low Apgar score, admission to NICU, hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE), neonatal death, rarely stillbirth.

A 55-year-old Asian woman presents with acute eye pain and blurred vision. Her ophthalmologist suspects primary angle closure glaucoma (PACG). Which of the following statements about the etiopathogenesis of PACG is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Pupillary block is the most common mechanism in PACG

options.label: B
options.text: Phacomorphic mechanism involves an abnormally large lens pushing the iris forward

options.label: C
options.text: Plateau iris configuration is more common in younger patients with PACG

options.label: D
options.text: Caucasians have a higher prevalence of PACG compared to other ethnicities

questions.correct_answer: D. Caucasians have a higher prevalence of PACG compared to other ethnicities
questions.explanation:
Risk Factors

Mechanisms

Demographic factors:

  • Age: 6th and 7th decades of life
  • Gender: Female to male ratio 1:3
  • Ethnicity: More common in Asians

1. Pupillary block (70% of cases): (Option A ruled out)

  • Most common mechanism (70% of cases)
  • Increased contact between iris and lens
  • Precipitating factors:
    • Physiological mydriasis (e.g., dim illumination, emotional stress)
    • Pharmacological mydriasis (e.g., tropicamide, cyclopentolate)
  • Results in relative pupil block

Anatomical factors:

  • Hypermetropic eyes
  • Shallow anterior chamber
  • Short axial length
  • Thick, anteriorly positioned lens
  • Small corneal diameter
  • Plateau iris configuration

2. Plateau iris configuration:

  • Anteriorly positioned ciliary processes
  • More common in younger patients (Option C ruled out)
  • Can persist after iridotomy
  • Associated with angle closure glaucoma without pupillary block

Other factors:

  • Family history
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Certain medications (e.g., topiramate)

3. Phacomorphic mechanism: (Option B ruled out)

  • Swollen lens contributes to angle closure
  • Can cause pupillary block or push peripheral iris forward
  • Can occur in acute or chronic forms
  • Associated with intumescent or other lens morphological abnormalities

questions.text: Which of the following mortality indicators is a positive mortality indicator?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Reference:

Crude death rate

CDR = (Total no. or deaths in a community/ MYP (Mid-year population) in the same area) x 100

  • The mid-year population is taken on 1st July
  • Limitation: It does not consider the age and sex of the population

Age-specific death rate (Option A)

ASDR = (Total no. of deaths in a particular age group (eg. 20-24yrs) a given area in a year/ MYP of the age group in the same area and year) x 1000

Expectation of life

(Option C)
  • Life expectancy at birth: A positive mortality indicator· Average no. of years a newborn is expected to live, considering the current age-specific mortality rates in a community.
  • Important component to calculate the Human Development Index (HDI).
  • Life expectancy at one year is PQLI. In 2021, life expectancy in India is 69.7 years.

Infant mortality rate

IMR = (Total number of deaths (0-1-year-old) in a given year / Total number of live births in the same year) x 1000. It is a health status indicator.

Under-five mortality rate

U5MR = (Total number of deaths (0-5 years old) in a given year /Total number of live births in one year) x 1000

Maternal Mortality Rate

Maternal Mortality Rate (MMR) = (Total no. of maternal deaths/women in the reproductive age group [15-49 years]) x 100,000

Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR)

Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) = (Total no. of maternal deaths/Live Births) x 100,000

Adult mortality rate

Probability of dying between 15 to 60 years of life

Year of potential life lost (Option D)

Premature death measurement. If life expectancy is 75 years, and death happens at age 30, then 45 years of potential life is lost

Proportional mortality rate (Option B)

The simplest measure of the burden of disease (Total deaths due to disease 'x'/ Total deaths in a community)́ x 100

Case fatality rate

CFR = (Deaths due to diseases ‘z’ / total no of cases of disease ‘z’) x 100

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with irritation and redness at both eye corners, foamy discharge, and skin maceration as shown below. He also has chronic nasal discharge. Which organism is most likely causing his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Angular Conjunctivitis

Type of chronic conjunctivitis characterized by mild inflammation confined to the conjunctiva and lid margins near the angles of the eyes, associated with maceration of the surrounding skin.

Causative Agent
  • Moraxella axenfeld is the most common cause, leading to the term "diplobacillary conjunctivitis" due to the bacilli being arranged end-to-end.
  • Rarely Staphylococci.

Source of Infection

Nasal Cavity

Mode of Transmission

Infection is transmitted from the nasal cavity to the eyes via contaminated fingers or handkerchiefs.

Pathology

The bacillus produces proteolytic enzymes that macerate the epithelium, resulting in mild chronic inflammation and eczematous changes in the skin around the eye angles.

Symptoms

  • Irritation
  • Burning sensation
  • Discomfort in the eyes

Signs

  • Hyperemia of the bulbar conjunctiva and lid margins near the angles
  • Excoriation of the skin around the angles
  • Foamy mucopurulent discharge at the angles

Image

Complications
  • Blepharitis
  • Shallow marginal catarrhal corneal ulceration

Treatment

  • Oxytetracycline (1%) eye ointment applied 2-3 times a day for 9-14 days.
  • Zinc lotion instilled during the day, and zinc oxide ointment at bedtime to inhibit the proteolytic enzyme and reduce maceration.

  • Myelination: Increases conduction velocity, enabling saltatory conduction. (Option D)
  • Axon Diameter: Larger diameter axons exhibit faster conduction velocities. (Option A)
  • Temperature: Higher temperatures increase ion channel opening and closing speeds affecting conduction velocity.

 

Classification of Nerve Fibers
  • Larger, myelinated fibers (like Aα fibers) - Faster conduction velocity.
  • Smaller, unmyelinated fibers (like C fibers) - Slower conduction velocity.

Clinical Significance

 

  • A decrease in chronaxie after nerve repair suggests increased excitability and potential regeneration.

Stimulus Strength

  • A stronger stimulus doesn't increase the speed of an action potential in a single nerve fiber, it might activate a greater number of fibers.

A 50 y/o man undergoes a total hip replacement. Postoperatively, he develops difficulty walking and reports numbness along the posterior thigh, lateral leg, and sole of the foot. O/E, he has weakness in extending the hip and flexing the knee. The injured nerve originates from which of the following spinal roots?
questions.explanation:
Sciatic Nerve

Origin and Course
  • The thickest nerve in the body.
  • Arises from the ventral rami of L4–S3 spinal nerves. (Option A, C & D ruled out)
  • Exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen below the piriformis and descends between the greater trochanter and ischial tuberosity along the back of the thigh.
  • Divides into the tibial and common peroneal nerves above the popliteal fossa.

Distribution

Motor:

  • Undivided Trunk: Supplies all muscles of the back of the thigh (hip extension, knee flexion).
  • Tibial Nerve: Innervates leg muscles (flexion) and foot muscles (plantar flexion).
  • Common Peroneal Nerve: Supplies leg muscles (dorsiflexion).

Sensory:

  • Tibial Nerve: Supplies skin on the back of the calf, heel, lateral border of the foot, and sole.
  • Common Peroneal Nerve: Supplies skin on the anterolateral and lateral surfaces of the leg and dorsum of the foot (except for the deep peroneal nerve area).

Clinical correlation

Injury of the sciatic nerve:

  • Causes: Penetrating wounds, posterior hip dislocation, pelvic fractures, total hip replacement, misplaced injections in the gluteal region.
  • Clinical Features:
  • Inability to extend the thigh and flex the knee (hamstring paralysis).
  • Loss of all movements below the knee (foot drop) leading to flail foot and high-stepping gait.
  • Loss of sensation on the back of the thigh, entire leg, and foot (except for the saphenous nerve area).

Sciatica:

  • Shooting pain along the sciatic nerve distribution (buttock, posterior thigh, lateral leg, dorsum of the foot).
  • Compression/irritation of L4–S3 spinal nerve roots due to herniated lumbar discs.

Neuropathy:

  • Entrapment in the piriformis muscle can lead to piriformis syndrome.

questions.text: An egg was extracted and observed under the microscope. Which of the following species does it belong to?
questions.explanation:
Hymenolepis nana (Dwarf Tapeworm)

Hymenolepis nana, or dwarf tapeworm, is a parasitic cestode primarily infecting humans and rodents, commonly causing infection in children.

It can complete its life cycle in a single host without requiring an intermediate host.

Morphology
  • Adult Worm: Measures 15–40 mm in length; features a scolex with four suckers and a retractable rostellum with hooks for attachment to the intestinal wall.
  • Proglottids: Segmented body, with each segment containing both male and female reproductive organs.

Life Cycle
  • Infective Stage: Eggs are excreted in feces and can survive in the environment.
  • Autoinfection: Ingested eggs hatch in the intestine, allowing direct development into adults, leading to reinfection.
  • Ingestion: Humans acquire infection by consuming contaminated food or water. Rodents can also act as hosts.
  • Larval Development: Oncospheres hatch in the intestine, penetrate intestinal villi, and develop into cysticercoids.
  • Maturation: Cysticercoids mature into adults in about 20–30 days, attaching to the intestinal wall and producing eggs.

Clinical features
  • Asymptomatic in many cases.
  • Symptomatic individuals may experience:
    • Abdominal pain and cramps
    • Diarrhea or loose stools
    • Loss of appetite and weight loss
    • Irritability (especially in children)
    • Nausea and vomiting (less common)

Investigations
  • Stool Examination: Microscopic detection of eggs using methods like Kato-Katz or concentration techniques.
  • PCR: Used for specific identification of H. nana DNA in stool samples.

Management

Antiparasitic Medication:

  • Praziquantel: First-line treatment, typically a single oral dose of 25 mg/kg.
  • Alternative: Nitazoxanide.

Features

Taenia Species

Diphyllobothrium latum

Hymenolepis nana

Hymenolepis diminuta

Egg Appearance

Brownish/yellow-brown, thick-shelled

Yellow-brown, operculated


 

Colourless to yellow-brown, thin-shelled



 

Similar to H. nana, slightly larger



 

Size (Diameter)

30-43 µm

50-76 µm

30-45 µm

40-70 µm

Shape

Spherical/ovoid

Ellipsoidal

Oval to Spherical

Oval to Spherical

Shell Characteristics

Striated (thick)

Operculum at one end, thin shell

Smooth, no striations

Smooth, no striations

Bile Staining

Negative

Positive

Negative

Negative

Other Features

Contains hooks in the larval stage (cysticercus); no hooks in T. saginata

Terminal knob at the opposite end

Contains polar filaments

Polar filaments, typically absent

Embryo Development

Cysticercus larva can develop within the host

Proglottids shed in water, release eggs

Can develop into an adult in a single host.

Requires an intermediate host (usually rodents)

questions.text: Match the following corneal assessment techniques with their correct descriptions: 1) Keratometry a) Measures both anterior and posterior corneal surfaces. 2) Placido's Disc b) Assesses the smoothness and curvature of the corneal surface. 3) Corneal Topography c) Evaluate the anterior curvature of the cornea and generate colour-coded maps. 4) Corneal Tomography (Pentacam) d) Measures the curvature of the central cornea.
questions.explanation:
Instrument

Image

Keratometry:

  • An objective method for measuring the curvature of the central cornea to estimate corneal astigmatism.
  • Principle of Keratometer: Measures corneal curvature by analyzing the size of the image formed by the anterior corneal surface, utilizing visible doubling.
  • Normal Keratometric Values:
    • Average: 45 D
    • Keratoconus >45 D
  • Types of Keratometers:
    • Javal-Schiotz Model
    • Bausch & Lomb Model
 

Auto refractive Keratometer

Keratoscopy or placido's disc:

  • A disc with alternating black and white circles.
  • Assesses the smoothness and curvature of the corneal surface.
  • Normal Observation: Uniform, sharp image of circles on the cornea.
  • Irregularities on cornea: Distort the circles

Corneal topography:

  • Evaluates the anterior curvature of the cornea.
  • Generates colour-coded maps of the corneal surface's shape, curvature, and elevation.
  • Diagnoses conditions like keratoconus.
  • Assists in planning refractive surgeries.
  • Does not provide information about the posterior corneal surface.

Corneal tomography (Pentacam):

  • Measures both anterior and posterior corneal surfaces.
  • Provides a three-dimensional view of corneal structure.
  • Identifies subclinical keratoconus.
  • Assesses candidates for keratorefractive surgery.
  • Uses Scheimpflug imaging for high accuracy in corneal measurements.
  • Valuable for preoperative evaluations and monitoring disease progression.

A 9-month-old infant presented with sudden choking on a small toy part while playing. The infant appears cyanotic and is making weak, ineffective attempts to breathe. What is the most appropriate initial intervention for this infant?
questions.explanation:
Causes

Choking on small objects such as toy parts, seeds, nuts, grapes, pebbles, or buttons.

Presentation

Sudden onset of cough, gagging or stridor with or without respiratory distress.

Type of Obstruction
  • Severe Obstruction: Universal choking sign (clutching the neck), weak or no cough, inability to speak or breathe, cyanosis.
  • Mild Obstruction: Breathing is possible, with possible wheezing, coughing, and stridor.

Immediate Removal Indication

Severe obstruction requires urgent intervention.

Procedure for Infants (<1 year)
  • Back Blows: Place the infant face down over the rescuer’s arm, head lower than the trunk, and deliver five back blows between the scapulae. (Option C)
  • Chest Compressions: If obstruction persists, turn the infant over and perform five chest compressions. (Option B)
  • Sequence: Repeat back blows and chest compressions until the obstruction is relieved or the infant becomes unconscious.
  •  

 

Procedure for Children (>1 year)

(Option A)

Heimlich Maneuver: Perform abdominal thrusts.

 

Complications

  • Chest Compressions: May cause rib or cardiac damage, though rare.
  • Heimlich Maneuver: If performed incorrectly, the manoeuvre can cause pneumomediastinum, rupture of the spleen or stomach, and injury to the aorta.

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician due to poor weight gain, vomiting, and yellowing of the skin and eyes. Type

Symptoms

Healed Chorioretinal Lesions: White, atrophic areas with choroidal thinning; black pigment clumping at edges

questions.text: Match the following drugs to their mechanism of action: a) Aspirin i) Inhibits COX 3 b) Meloxicam ii) Inhibits COX 1 and 2 c) Parecoxib iii) Inhibits COX 2 > COX1 d) Paracetamol iv) Inhibits only COX 2

questions.text: If a healthcare provider temporarily uses a domestic refrigerator to store vaccines, where should he place the Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) and Measles vaccines inside the refrigerator?
questions.explanation:
Domestic Refrigerator Usage

Details

Vaccine Storage

Can be used for storing vaccines at private clinics and nursing homes, but hold-over time and capacity are limited. Requires a guaranteed continuous power supply.

Temperature Range

Maintains a cabinet temperature between +2°C to +8°C.

Placement of Vaccines
(Options A, B, C, D)
  • Top Shelf: Measles, BCG, Rotavirus vaccine, OPV
  • Middle Shelf: DPT, Pentavalent vaccine, TT, IPV, Hepatitis B, and diluents placed next to their corresponding vaccines.
  • Bottom Shelf: Water-filled ice packs to help maintain temperature stability.
  • Door: Avoid storing vaccines in the door as they experience the most temperature fluctuation

Ice Pack Usage

Place ice packs filled with water on the bottom shelf and in the refrigerator door to help maintain the temperature in case of a power outage.

Temperature Monitoring

A dial thermometer is placed inside the refrigerator to monitor the temperature twice daily.

A 2-year-old child presents with polyuria, growth failure, fair skin, blond hair, and photophobia. Slit-lamp examination reveals cystine crystals in the cornea. Which genetic mutation is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Cystinosis

Etiology

Mutations in the CTNS gene (Option C) (encoding the protein cystinosin, a cystine transporter) → Defect in cystinosin → Accumulation of cystine crystals in major organs (kidney, liver, eyes, brain)

Clinical Features
  • Severe tubular dysfunction, Fanconi syndrome, polyuria, polydipsia, growth failure, rickets, progressive tubulointerstitial fibrosis
  • Fever due to dehydration or diminished sweat production.
  • Fair skin, and blond hair due to diminished pigmentation.
  • Ocular issues: photophobia, retinopathy, impaired visual acuity.
  • Other features: hypothyroidism, hepatosplenomegaly, delayed sexual maturation.

Diagnosis
  • Detection of cystine crystals in the cornea.
  • Confirmed by measuring increased cystine content in leukocytes.

Treatment
  • Therapy with cysteamine (converts cystine to cysteine)
  • Cysteamine eye drops for ocular involvement.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient comes to your clinic with complaints of glare and diminution of vision for 3 months. On examination, you notice the following appearance Choose the correct statement regarding the correct diagnosis.

options.label: A
options.text: The Iris shadow test becomes positive only when the whole cortex is involved.

options.label: B
options.text: Patients see better in dark surroundings.

options.label: C
options.text: Characterized by saucer-shaped opacities in the center of the posterior cortex.

options.label: D
options.text: Vision loss occurs at a late stage.

questions.correct_answer: D. Vision loss occurs at a late stage.
questions.explanation:
Type of Cataract

Characteristics

Visual Impact

Cuneiform Senile Cortical Cataract
  • Wedge-shaped opacities with clear areas in between.
  • Extends from periphery to center.
  • First appears in the lower nasal quadrant. Present in both anterior and posterior cortex.
  • The radial spoke-like pattern of opacities is seen.
  • Visual disturbances are noted at a comparatively late stage (since it starts at the periphery). (Option D)
  • Vision improves in bright light with contracted pupils. (Option B)

Cupuliform Senile Cortical Cataract

  • Saucer-shaped opacities are typically in the central part of the posterior cortex (posterior subcapsular cataract). (Option C)
  • Extends from center to periphery.
  • Causes an early loss of visual acuity.- Due to the involvement of the nodal point
  • Glares seen in PSC
  • Better vision in dim light with dilated pupils.

Stage

Description

Characteristics

1. Stage of Lamellar Separation

Earliest stage of senile cataract
  • Formation of vacuoles and water clefts within the cortex
  • Reversible change
  • Can only be demonstrated by slit lamp examination

2. Stage of Incipient Cataract

Detectable opacities with clear areas present between. Causes visual disturbances.

Cuneiform type:

  • Wedge-shaped opacities, extending from the equator appear as radial spoke-like opacities.

Cupuliform type:

  • Saucer-shaped opacity in the central posterior cortex.

3. Immature Senile Cataract

Progression of opacification
  • Iris shadow visible (clear cortex visible) -Iris Shadow present here due to opacities + clear areas(Option A)
  • Can progress to Intumescent Cataract leading to the shallow anterior chamber.

4. Mature Senile Cataract (aka intumescent cataract)

Complete opacification of cortex
  • The lens appears pearly white
  • Referred to as a "ripe cataract"
  • No iris shadow as the whole lens is opacified with a chalky white color

5. Hypermature Senile Cataract (HMSC)

Advanced stage of cataract beyond maturity

Morgagnian Hypermature Cataract:

  • Cortex liquefies
  • Nucleus sinks to the bottom
  • Bag of milky fluid appearance

Sclerotic Hypermature Cataract:

  • The cortex disintegrates, lens and capsule shrink.
  • Deep anterior chamber
  • Iridodonesis may be present.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with six months of dysphagia, regurgitation, and a feeling of food getting stuck, often coughing while eating. A barium swallow study shows specific findings on the radiograph. Which muscle pairs define the anatomical boundaries of the observed dehiscence?

options.label: D
options.text: Inferior constrictor along with upper esophageal muscle fibres

questions.explanation:
Description

An acquired, false, and pulsion diverticulum formed by the protrusion of mucosa and submucosa through Killian's dehiscence.

Clinical manifestations
  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Food getting stuck (leading to coughing while eating)
  • Aspiration
  • Halitosis (bad breath)

Investigation

Barium swallow reveals an outpouching of the pharyngeal mucosa above the upper oesophagal sphincter, often with slow emptying of the diverticulum.

 

Management

  • Diverticulectomy and cricopharyngeal myotomy: Surgical removal of the diverticulum and myotomy of the cricopharyngeal muscle.
  • Diverticular suspension: Dissection and inversion of the diverticulum with its apex pointing cranially.
  • Myotomy through stapler transection: Transoral insertion of a linear stapler to divide the septum between the diverticulum and the true oesophagal lumen.

Dohlman Procedure: Endoscopic technique involving division of the diverticulum wall and cricopharyngeal myotomy.

Killian’s dehiscence

A weak area situated between the two components of the inferior constrictor muscle: the thyropharyngeus and the cricopharyngeus.

Laimer’s dehiscence

A midline structure situated below Killian’s dehiscence formed by the cricopharyngeus muscle and the upper circular muscle fibres of the esophagus.

Killian Jamieson's area

A dehiscence situated laterally and inferiorly to the inferior constrictor muscle, formed by the inferior constrictor muscle and the upper fibres of the oesophagus.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a 10-year history of chronic GORD presents for a follow-up endoscopy. The endoscopy shows a 3 cm segment of salmon-colored mucosa extending above the OGJ with biopsy-proven intestinal metaplasia. He has no nodularity or ulceration. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.text: High-dose proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy and aspirin

questions.correct_answer: C. High-dose proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy and aspirin
questions.explanation:
Barrett's Esophagus

Definition

Complication of GORD

Columnar epithelium >1 cm above OGJ

Endoscopic Landmarks

OGJ: proximal end of gastric folds, not diaphragmatic pinch/squamocolumnar junction

Classification

Prague C&M: circumferential (C) and maximal (M) extent

Risk Factors
  • Chronic GORD
  • Age >50
  • Smoking
  • Central obesity
  • Male

Cancer Risk
  • Non-dysplastic: 0.2–0.5%/year
  • Low-grade: 0.7%/year
  • High-grade: 7%/year

Screening
  • Early identification/treatment

Treatment
  • Treat underlying GORD, same pharmacological therapy as symptomatic GORD
  • Chemoprevention: Aspirin + high-dose PPI improves outcomes (Option C)
  • Dysplastic Treatment: Ablate/resect without invasive cancer, controversial in non-dysplastic
  • Ablative Therapy: Flat lesions only, RFA preferred
  • EMR vs ESD
    • EMR: easier, piecemeal;
    • ESD: en bloc, better margins

Post-Treatment

Surveillance for recurrence/persistent Barrett's or neoplasia

questions.explanation:
Alpha (α) rays:

Particles emitted by the nucleus through α decay, containing 2 protons and 2 neutrons.

Beta (β) rays:

Particles emitted by the nucleus through β decay, either electrons/positrons

Gamma (γ) rays:

Photons emitted by the nucleus.

Ionizing power: (damaging capacity of linear energy transfer - LET)

Alpha (α) > Beta (β) > X-Rays > Gamma (γ) rays

Penetration power:

Neutrons > Gamma (γ)rays >Beta (β)rays >Alpha (α)rays

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a bladder tumor invading the muscle layer is classified as which TNM stage?
questions.explanation:
Primary Tumor Staging (TNM System)

The depth of invasion of the primary tumor in bladder cancer is a crucial prognostic factor for recurrence and progression.

Ta Lesions

(Option A)

Papillary (exophytic) tumors with a tendency to recur.

Tis Lesions

High-grade intraepithelial neoplasms (carcinoma in situ [CIS]) without invasion into subepithelial connective tissue.

T1 Lesions

(Option B)

Tumors invade the submucosa or lamina propria, typically high-grade.

T2 Lesions

(Option C)

Tumors invade muscle; cystectomy is standard therapy.

Presence of muscle invasion increases the likelihood of nodal and distant metastases.

T3 Lesions

(Option D)

Tumors extend beyond muscle into perivesical fat. Imaging (CT, MRI, PET) may help identify disease spread outside the bladder.

T4 Lesions

Tumors extend into adjacent organs.

T4a - invasion into the prostate, vagina, uterus, or bowel

T4b - tumors fixed to the abdominal wall, pelvic wall, or other organs.

Regional Lymph Nodes & Distant Metastases

Description

N1

Involvement of a single lymph node within the true pelvis.

N2

Involvement of multiple lymph nodes within the true pelvis.

N3

Spread to the common iliac lymph nodes.

M1a

Lymph node involvement beyond the common iliac lymph nodes.

M1b

Involvement of distant organs (non-lymph node distant metastases).

questions.explanation:

  • Ionic = 2 particles
  • Non-ionic = 1 particle

  • Dimer = 6 iodine

Ionic Monomer

Ionic Dimer

Non-ionic Monomer

Non-ionic Dimer

3:2

(High osmolality)

3:1

(Low osmolality)

3:1

6:1

Iodine Contrast

Routes of administration

Intravenous and Intra-arterial


 

Indications

Commonly used for contrast in CECT (3D X-ray), Interventional Radiology, and X-rays like as in

  • Intravenous pyelogram
  • Micturating cystourethrogram
  • Hysterosalpingography
  • Retrograde pyelography
  • ERCP- Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography

Adverse Reactions

Physiological Reactions

Allergic Reactions

Post-contrast induced nephropathy
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Flushing
  • Headaches
  • Vasovagal reaction
  • Arrhythmias
  • Seizures
 

-

Mild reactions:

  • Hives (Urticaria)
  • Erythema (Redness of skin)
 

Moderate to severe reactions:

  • Wheezing
  • Anaphylactoid reactions (Non-IgE mediated)
  • Also known as Contrast-Induced Acute Kidney Injury (AKI).
  • It is defined as an increase in serum creatinine by > 0.5 mg/dL or a > 25% rise from the baseline within 3 days of contrast administration, without any other clear cause.
  • Risk factors:
    • Patients with pre-existing kidney disease.
    • Pre-contrast eGFR < 60 mL/min/1.73 m² indicates higher risk.

Management:

Observation for mild reactions

Management:

  • Mild reactions: Antihistamines (e.g., Diphenhydramine)
  • Severe reactions: Requires epinephrine and advanced airway management as needed.

Management:

Intravenous hydration (e.g., normal saline)
